title: 111_hr2147
content: The Act titled "Global Warming Economic Oversight Act of 2009" establishes the Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission is established to conduct ongoing oversight and submit reports to Congress on the use of funds from greenhouse gas emissions allowances auctions or sales. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission will report to Congress every 3 months after the first auction of greenhouse gas emissions allowances, focusing on specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission will focus on using funds to create new jobs in renewable energy industries, preserve existing jobs in carbon-intensive industries, assist low and middle-income families with increased costs, and help small businesses with energy cost increases. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission aims to assist small businesses with energy cost increases resulting from Federal statutes on greenhouse gas emissions. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various congressional leaders. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission consists of 9 members appointed by congressional leaders, including the Secretary of Energy, the Chairperson of the Federal Trade Commission, and the Administrator of the Small Business. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission consists of appointed members including the Administrator of the Small Business Administration and the Secretary of Labor. Members are paid based on the Executive Schedule and federal employees are prohibited from receiving compensation. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission members, including federal employees, are prohibited from receiving additional pay. Members receive travel expenses and a quorum consists of four members. Vacancies are filled as per original appointment and meetings are called by the Chair or majority of members. Staff support is provided. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission may appoint personnel, experts, and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission has the power to administer oaths, take actions authorized by the Commission, obtain official data from US departments, and must begin operations within 30 days of the first auction of greenhouse gas emissions allowances. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents to carry out its duties, with the Chair having the power to issue subpoenas. The Commission may establish rules for its business operations, as long as they comply with the Act and other laws. The Global Warming Economic Oversight Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents either by the Chair or by a vote of 5 members. Subpoenas can be signed by the Chair or a designated member and enforced in cases of non-compliance. The United States district court can issue an order for a person to testify or produce evidence in case of non-compliance with a subpoena. Failure to obey the court's order may result in contempt of court. The Commission can certify a statement of fact to the United States attorney if a person fails to comply with a subpoena, who may then bring the matter before a grand jury. The Commission is authorized to enter into contracts to fulfill its duties under this Act. The Commission may use the United States mails, accept voluntary services, terminate after the last greenhouse gas emissions auction, and receive necessary appropriations to carry out its duties under this Act.
